intro: Potamogeton × crassifolius, commonly known as the broad-leaved pondweed, is a hybrid aquatic plant that combines traits from its parent species, Potamogeton perfoliatus and Potamogeton crispus. It is characterized by its broad, flat leaves that are often ribbed and can grow up to 15 cm in length. This plant typically thrives in freshwater environments such as lakes, ponds, and slow-moving rivers. Its roots are fibrous and help stabilize the sediment, while its stems are flexible and can float or submerge. It reproduces both sexually through seeds and asexually through vegetative propagation, making it a common and persistent species in aquatic ecosystems.
